rawContent:
Universality and AGI resources

@DavidDeutschOxf  in BoI
(from memory, maybe inaccurate)
- explanatory universality is analogous to computational universality
- just as there does not exist a more general computer than the universal Turing machine, there isn't a more universal explainer than a human
- entities that achieve universality are fundamentally the same kind of thing, though may differ in processing speed and memory size.
- it is provably possible for other entities to achieve human-level intelligence because brains are physical objects and a universal Turing machine can simulate any physical object to arbitrarily fine detail
- there is no continuum of intelligence between a human and an AGI, no thought that one could think and the other could not (in principle, bounded by memory/speed?)

@dela3499 breaks down universality https://t.co/slRzySJYJw
- 4 types of universality required for human-level intelligence
- computational universality: any idea is thinkable
- creative reach: starting from some point in idea space, you can reach any other point through creativity
- abstraction/chunking: ideas can be chunked to take larger and larger steps in the space of ideas
- comparison and selection: "To create consists precisely in not making useless combinations and in making those which are useful and which are only a small minority. Invention is discernment, choice." - Henri Poincaré

@DavidDeutschOxf in "How close are we to AGI" https://t.co/OHcgivkNOZ
- an AGI will be capable of thinking the same ideas, and running the same cognitive processes as us (consciousness, emotions, boredom, disobedience...)
- it would be cruel and immoral to abuse an AGI because it can suffer just like a human, even if we could never prove it was "really" suffering? (unsure if this is an accurate summary)

@ToKTeacher: denying explanatory universality is a supernaturalist argument: https://t.co/xRkOl9Visg
- to deny that humans are universal explainers is a dead end because you don't know if a problem (eg. to explain phenomenon X) is solvable until you try

@dwarkesh_sp has some interesting counter-arguments against humans as universal explainers https://t.co/TCnYgXoV36
- The universal explainer hypothesis does not explain why some animals are smart and some humans are stupid, ie it seems like intelligence is a spectrum
- Suppose it were true, speed and memory differences between a human and AGI means there's still a spectrum of intelligence and AGI would have the advantage
- It doesn't appear to be the case that for all humans all ideas are thinkable
- The Scaling Hypothesis is a better explanation of intelligence

rawContent: RT @zdrks: In case anyone is curious how I might go about remembering some information using flashcards.

user.rawDescription: Trust the tale, not the teller.

retweetedTweet.rawContent: In case anyone is curious how I might go about remembering some information using flashcards.

user.rawDescription: Trust the tale, not the teller.

quotedTweet.rawContent:
Here are some flashcards for this. I could add some more to cover some very specific details, but this should cover the meat of it. Curious to hear your thoughts. I wasn't very familiar with most of this, so it may be worth double checking anything that sounds off.

——

Q. What is the trend for the Colorado River's flow (increasing or decreasing)?
A. Decreasing (due to climate change)

Q. What is the main cause of the downward trend in the Colorado River's flow?
A. Climate change

Q. What is the total annual water usage from the Colorado River for Los Angeles and the Imperial Valley?
A. Over 5 million acre-feet (MAF)

Q. Which river provides over 5 MAF of water annually to Los Angeles and the Imperial Valley?
A. The Colorado River

Q. What is the primary cause of the increasing salinity in the Salton Sea?
A. The lake's water level dropping due to evaporation.

Q. Why can't fish survive in the Salton Sea anymore?
A. The salinity is too high (due to the water level dropping from evaporation)

Q. When did the Salton Sea experience several great fish die-offs?
A. In the early 2010s (due to increasing salinity from the dropping water level)

Q. What is one of the main health consequences for communities around the Salton Sea due to its decreasing water level?
A. Severe and widespread respiratory problems (from dust from the exposed lake bed)

Q. What is the primary reason for the Salton Sea's decreasing water level?
A. Evaporation

Q. Name at least one effect of the Salton Sea's increasing salinity.
A. e.g., Fish can no longer survive (leading to great die-offs in the early 2010s).

Q. What happened to fish populations in the Salton Sea during the early 2010s?
A. There were several great die-offs (due to high salinity)

Q. What type of desalination plant does Casey Handmer propose building?
A. A reverse osmosis desalination plant

Q. What energy source would power the desalination plant, according to Casey Handmer's proposal?
A. Solar photovoltaic panels

Q. How does the economic productivity of solar photovoltaic panels compare to farming (acre for acre)?
A. 100 times more productive

Q. Acre for acre, solar photovoltaic panels are 100 times more economically productive than […].
A. farming

Q. What are the two main goals of Handmer's proposed reverse osmosis desalination plant?
A. To alleviate ecological pressures and guarantee water abundance for the southwest.

Q. What recent development makes it feasible to restore the Salton Sea, according to Casey Handmer?
A. The availability of cheap electricity from solar photovoltaic panels.

Q. Where would Handmer's proposed desalination plant be built?
A. In the desert west of Yuma

Q. Why is the location west of Yuma convenient for Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. It is close to existing irrigation canals and the Colorado river.

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with sea water?
A. A pipeline from the Gulf of California

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. A spur line parallel to the Coachella Canal

Q. What body of water would the pipeline for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Gulf of California

Q. What body of water would the spur line for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Salton Sea

Q. What canal runs parallel to the spur line that feeds Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. The Coachella Canal

Q. What type of energy would power Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. Solar PV

Q. What process would Handmer's proposed desalination plant use to treat water?
A. Reverse osmosis (RO)

Q. What are the two output streams from the RO process in Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. Fresh water and concentrated brine (~6% salinity)

Q. What is the salinity of the incoming water to Handmer's proposed RO desalination plant?
A. ~3%

Q. What is the salinity of the concentrated brine output from the RO process in Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. ~6%

Q. What is the salinity of the fresh water output from the RO process in Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. 0% (it's fresh water)

Q. In Handmer's proposal, what is done with the fresh water output from the RO desalination process?
A. Distributed into irrigation canals (and potentially municipal water supplies)

Q. In Handmer's proposal, what is done with the concentrated brine output from the RO desalination process?
A. Fed to adjacent brine processing facilities

Q. In Handmer's proposal, what do the brine processing facilities adjacent to the desalination plant do?
A. Extract valuable metals from the concentrated brine (using solar and geothermal energy)

Q. In Handmer's proposal, what happens to the depleted brine after valuable metals are extracted at the brine processing facilities?
A. It is piped back to the ocean, mixed with sea water, and discharged.

Q. Name at least two valuable metals that could be extracted from concentrated brine at the brine processing facilities in Handmer's proposal.
A. Lithium, sodium, magnesium, chloride (and other metals found in sea water)

Q. Where would Handmer's proposed desalination plant be built?
A. In the desert west of Yuma

Q. Why is the location west of Yuma convenient for Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. It is close to existing irrigation canals and the Colorado river.

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with sea water?
A. A pipeline from the Gulf of California

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. A spur line parallel to the Coachella Canal

Q. What body of water would the pipeline for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Gulf of California

Q. What body of water would the spur line for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Salton Sea

Q. What canal runs parallel to the spur line that feeds Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. The Coachella Canal

Q. Name at least two potential sources of revenue for Handmer's proposed desalination project in Yuma.
A. Water sales, brine products, and land value appreciation (from restoring the Salton Sea)

Q. How could restoring the Salton Sea indirectly lead to revenue for Handmer's proposed desalination project?
A. By causing land value appreciation in the surrounding area (which would become more habitable)

Q. How much electricity did the world deploy from solar in 2023?
A. 450 GW

Q. In what year did solar energy deployment reach 450 GW globally?
A. 2023

Q. What has changed in the last decade to make large-scale desalination more feasible?
A. The cost of solar energy has decreased significantly.

user.rawDescription: Trust the tale, not the teller.

A. Extract valuable metals from the concentrated brine (using solar and geothermal energy)

Q. In Handmer's proposal, what happens to the depleted brine after valuable metals are extracted at the brine processing facilities?
A. It is piped back to the ocean, mixed with sea water, and discharged.

Q. Name at least two valuable metals that could be extracted from concentrated brine at the brine processing facilities in Handmer's proposal.
A. Lithium, sodium, magnesium, chloride (and other metals found in sea water)

Q. Where would Handmer's proposed desalination plant be built?
A. In the desert west of Yuma

Q. Why is the location west of Yuma convenient for Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. It is close to existing irrigation canals and the Colorado river.

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with sea water?
A. A pipeline from the Gulf of California

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. A spur line parallel to the Coachella Canal

Q. What body of water would the pipeline for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Gulf of California

Q. What body of water would the spur line for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Salton Sea

Q. What canal runs parallel to the spur line that feeds Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. The Coachella Canal

Q. Name at least two potential sources of revenue for Handmer's proposed desalination project in Yuma.
A. Water sales, brine products, and land value appreciation (from restoring the Salton Sea)

Q. How could restoring the Salton Sea indirectly lead to revenue for Handmer's proposed desalination project?
A. By causing land value appreciation in the surrounding area (which would become more habitable)

Q. How much electricity did the world deploy from solar in 2023?
A. 450 GW

Q. In what year did solar energy deployment reach 450 GW globally?
A. 2023

Q. What has changed in the last decade to make large-scale desalination more feasible?
A. The cost of solar energy has decreased significantly.

rawContent: In case anyone is curious how I might go about remembering some information using flashcards.

user.rawDescription: Trust the tale, not the teller.

quotedTweet.rawContent:
Here are some flashcards for this. I could add some more to cover some very specific details, but this should cover the meat of it. Curious to hear your thoughts. I wasn't very familiar with most of this, so it may be worth double checking anything that sounds off.

——

Q. What is the trend for the Colorado River's flow (increasing or decreasing)?
A. Decreasing (due to climate change)

Q. What is the main cause of the downward trend in the Colorado River's flow?
A. Climate change

Q. What is the total annual water usage from the Colorado River for Los Angeles and the Imperial Valley?
A. Over 5 million acre-feet (MAF)

Q. Which river provides over 5 MAF of water annually to Los Angeles and the Imperial Valley?
A. The Colorado River

Q. What is the primary cause of the increasing salinity in the Salton Sea?
A. The lake's water level dropping due to evaporation.

Q. Why can't fish survive in the Salton Sea anymore?
A. The salinity is too high (due to the water level dropping from evaporation)

Q. When did the Salton Sea experience several great fish die-offs?
A. In the early 2010s (due to increasing salinity from the dropping water level)

Q. What is one of the main health consequences for communities around the Salton Sea due to its decreasing water level?
A. Severe and widespread respiratory problems (from dust from the exposed lake bed)

Q. What is the primary reason for the Salton Sea's decreasing water level?
A. Evaporation

Q. Name at least one effect of the Salton Sea's increasing salinity.
A. e.g., Fish can no longer survive (leading to great die-offs in the early 2010s).

Q. What happened to fish populations in the Salton Sea during the early 2010s?
A. There were several great die-offs (due to high salinity)

Q. What type of desalination plant does Casey Handmer propose building?
A. A reverse osmosis desalination plant

Q. What energy source would power the desalination plant, according to Casey Handmer's proposal?
A. Solar photovoltaic panels

Q. How does the economic productivity of solar photovoltaic panels compare to farming (acre for acre)?
A. 100 times more productive

Q. Acre for acre, solar photovoltaic panels are 100 times more economically productive than […].
A. farming

Q. What are the two main goals of Handmer's proposed reverse osmosis desalination plant?
A. To alleviate ecological pressures and guarantee water abundance for the southwest.

Q. What recent development makes it feasible to restore the Salton Sea, according to Casey Handmer?
A. The availability of cheap electricity from solar photovoltaic panels.

Q. Where would Handmer's proposed desalination plant be built?
A. In the desert west of Yuma

Q. Why is the location west of Yuma convenient for Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. It is close to existing irrigation canals and the Colorado river.

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with sea water?
A. A pipeline from the Gulf of California

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. A spur line parallel to the Coachella Canal

Q. What body of water would the pipeline for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Gulf of California

Q. What body of water would the spur line for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Salton Sea

Q. What canal runs parallel to the spur line that feeds Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. The Coachella Canal

Q. What type of energy would power Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. Solar PV

Q. What process would Handmer's proposed desalination plant use to treat water?
A. Reverse osmosis (RO)

Q. What are the two output streams from the RO process in Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. Fresh water and concentrated brine (~6% salinity)

Q. What is the salinity of the incoming water to Handmer's proposed RO desalination plant?
A. ~3%

Q. What is the salinity of the concentrated brine output from the RO process in Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. ~6%

Q. What is the salinity of the fresh water output from the RO process in Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. 0% (it's fresh water)

Q. In Handmer's proposal, what is done with the fresh water output from the RO desalination process?
A. Distributed into irrigation canals (and potentially municipal water supplies)

Q. In Handmer's proposal, what is done with the concentrated brine output from the RO desalination process?
A. Fed to adjacent brine processing facilities

Q. In Handmer's proposal, what do the brine processing facilities adjacent to the desalination plant do?
A. Extract valuable metals from the concentrated brine (using solar and geothermal energy)

Q. In Handmer's proposal, what happens to the depleted brine after valuable metals are extracted at the brine processing facilities?
A. It is piped back to the ocean, mixed with sea water, and discharged.

Q. Name at least two valuable metals that could be extracted from concentrated brine at the brine processing facilities in Handmer's proposal.
A. Lithium, sodium, magnesium, chloride (and other metals found in sea water)

Q. Where would Handmer's proposed desalination plant be built?
A. In the desert west of Yuma

Q. Why is the location west of Yuma convenient for Handmer's proposed desalination plant?
A. It is close to existing irrigation canals and the Colorado river.

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with sea water?
A. A pipeline from the Gulf of California

Q. What would feed Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. A spur line parallel to the Coachella Canal

Q. What body of water would the pipeline for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Gulf of California

Q. What body of water would the spur line for Handmer's proposed desalination plant draw from?
A. The Salton Sea

Q. What canal runs parallel to the spur line that feeds Handmer's proposed desalination plant with water from the Salton Sea?
A. The Coachella Canal

Q. Name at least two potential sources of revenue for Handmer's proposed desalination project in Yuma.
A. Water sales, brine products, and land value appreciation (from restoring the Salton Sea)

Q. How could restoring the Salton Sea indirectly lead to revenue for Handmer's proposed desalination project?
A. By causing land value appreciation in the surrounding area (which would become more habitable)

Q. How much electricity did the world deploy from solar in 2023?
A. 450 GW

Q. In what year did solar energy deployment reach 450 GW globally?
A. 2023

Q. What has changed in the last decade to make large-scale desalination more feasible?
A. The cost of solar energy has decreased significantly.

rawContent: RT @zdrks: AGI will reduce so much suffering in the world. Accelerate. Help people live lives that have less pain and disease.

user.rawDescription: Trust the tale, not the teller.

retweetedTweet.rawContent: AGI will reduce so much suffering in the world. Accelerate. Help people live lives that have less pain and disease.

user.rawDescription: President & Co-Founder @OpenAI

quotedTweet.rawContent:
A reason we need beneficial AGI:

After five years of pain across many systems in her body (a broken foot from stepping off a curb, debilitating migraines, fatigue, joint pain and instability, etc), my wife was recently diagnosed with a genetic disorder called Hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (hEDS).

Because the medical system is designed for individual specialties while hEDS affects every system in her body (orthopedics, cardiology, neurology, gastroenterology, dermatology, etc), we spent five years seeing more doctors and specialists than in her whole life prior. Most doctors would only focus on what was relevant to their own specialty. We were lucky that her allergist (!!) put together the pieces after observing and hearing her full set of symptoms and issues.

As human medicine has progressed, it seems like we increase doctors’ depth at the expense of breadth. We need better tools to be able to deliver depth and breadth simultaneously to patients. This is one promise of AGI if built right — reliable, individualized, affordable healthcare in your pocket, like a panel of today’s top doctors across every speciality working together in concert to keep you healthy (and without you needing to fax forms between them).

There’s still a long way to go on the technology and on learning how to deploy it beneficially along with appropriate professional human oversight in high-stakes areas like medicine, but the promise is getting increasingly clear. Thoughtfully approached by technology developers, healthcare providers, governments, and society, there’s hope for much better care for every member of all of our families (including our non-human furry ones).
